p.seg: Bei den topographischen Bestimmungen, die hier, wenn auch dem Hauptzwecke des Buches fremd, doch unentbehrlich waren, um eine Oertlichkeit zu erlangen, innerhalb deren sich die Erzählung bewegen könne, habe ich wohl gefühlt, wie misslich für den, welcher der eigenen Anschauung entbehrend nur fremden Berichten folgen kann, besonders eine in’s Einzelne gehende Beschreibung ist. Ich glaube indessen die wichtigsten Werke, welche von der Topographie dieses Theils von Griechenland handeln, so sorgfältig und zugleich so behutsam benutzt zu haben, dass ich nicht fürchten darf, es habe sich eine bedeutende Unrichtigkeit eingeschlichen, die zwar für die Hauptsache immer unwesentlich sein würde, deren Entfernung doch aber wünschenswerth bleibt. Für diesen Zweck habe ich ausser den Nachrichten von Strabo und Pausanias besonders gebraucht: Gell Itinerary of the Morea, Lond. 1817; Dodwell A classical and topographical tour through Greece, Lond. 1819, t. II; Leake, Travels in the Morea, Lond. 1830, t. III; Pouqueville Voyage dans la Grèce, Par. 1820, t. IV; und die Angaben der Expédition de Morée, Par. 1832 ff. t. II u. III. — Von Kleonä sagt

In the topographical determinations, which, although alien to the main purpose of the book, were nevertheless indispensable in order to obtain a place within which the narrative could move, I have well felt how unfortunate it is for the one who, lacking his own view, can only follow foreign reports, especially a detailed description. I believe, however, to have used the most important works dealing with the topography of this part of Greece so carefully and at the same time so carefully that I cannot fear that a significant inaccuracy has crept in, which would always be irrelevant for the main thing, but whose removal nevertheless remains desirable. For this purpose, in addition to the reports of Strabo and Pausanias, I have used in particular:

cit.quote: Κλεωναὶ δ᾽ εἰσὶ πόλισμα ἐπὶ τῇ ὁδῷ κείμενον τῇ ἐξ Ἄργους εἰς Κόρινθον. ἐπὶ λόφου περιοιχουμένου πανταχόϑεν καὶ τετειχισμένου καλῶς· ὥστ᾽ οἰκείως εἰρῆσϑαί μοι δοκεῖ τὸ ἐῠκτιμένας Κλεωνάς (Iliad. II, 570).

Cleonae is a small town located on the road from Argos to Corinth. It is built on a hill surrounded on all sides by a wall and is well fortified; so I think the phrase "well-built Cleonae" was aptly used.

p.seg:
Nach Leake t. III, p. 325 führt noch jetzt ein Weiler von vier oder fünf Häusern den Namen Klenäs (Κλέναις), während gewöhnlich Kurtési, ein grösseres Dorf, als an die Stelle der alten Stadt getreten genannt wird; vgl. Dodwell t. II, p. 206. [Nach E. Curtius Peloponnesos B. II, S. 511 hätten sich die Einwohner während des Mittelalters in das östliche Nebenthal gezogen und hierher den Stadtnamen in der Form Klenais übertragen. Bei C. Bursian, Geographie von
Griechenland, B. II, 8. 37 heisst es: „Die Stelle der Stadt auf einem an der Westseite des Thales gelegenen Hügel ist noch durch ihre Ruinen kenntlich,“ und 8. 38: „Noch heut zu Tage steht 1/4 Stunde südöstlich von ihrer Stelle ein Khan (der Khan von Kurtesa genannt) und eine Caserne daneben zur Erleichterung und Sicherung des Verkehrs, während im Uebrigen das Thal selbst verödet ist“].

According to Leake, vol. III, p. 325, a hamlet of four or five houses still bears the name Klenäs (Κλέναις), while Kurtési, a larger village, is generally referred to as the successor of the ancient city; see Dodwell, vol. II, p. 206. [According to E. Curtius, Peloponnesos, vol. II, p. 511, the inhabitants moved to the eastern tributary valley during the Middle Ages and transferred the city name to this place in the form of Klenais. In C. Bursian, Geographie von Griechenland, vol. II, p. 37, it says: "The site of the city on a hill on the west side of the valley is still recognizable by its ruins," and p. 38: "Even today, 1/4 hour southeast of its site, there is a khan (called the Khan of Kurtesa) and a barracks next to it to facilitate and secure traffic, while the valley itself has otherwise become deserted".]

In the topographical determinations, which, although alien to the main purpose of the book, were nevertheless indispensable in order to obtain a place within which the narrative could move, I have well felt how unfortunate it is for the one who, lacking his own view, can only follow foreign reports, especially a detailed description. I believe, however, to have used the most important works dealing with the topography of this part of Greece so carefully and at the same time so carefully that I cannot fear that a significant inaccuracy has crept in, which would always be irrelevant for the main thing, but whose removal nevertheless remains desirable. For this purpose, in addition to the reports of Strabo and Pausanias, I have used in particular:
Strabo VIII, 6, 19:
Κλεωναὶ δ᾽ εἰσὶ πόλισμα ἐπὶ τῇ ὁδῷ κείμενον τῇ ἐξ Ἄργους εἰς Κόρινθον. ἐπὶ λόφου περιοιχουμένου πανταχόϑεν καὶ τετειχισμένου καλῶς· ὥστ᾽ οἰκείως εἰρῆσϑαί μοι δοκεῖ τὸ ἐῠκτιμένας Κλεωνάς (Iliad. II,570).
Cleonae is a small town located on the road from Argos to Corinth. It is built on a hill surrounded on all sides by a wall and is well fortified; so I think the phrase "well-built Cleonae" was aptly used.
According to Leake, vol. III, p. 325, a hamlet of four or five houses still bears the name Klenäs (Κλέναις), while Kurtési, a larger village, is generally referred to as the successor of the ancient city; see Dodwell, vol. II, p. 206. [According to E. Curtius, Peloponnesos, vol. II, p. 511, the inhabitants moved to the eastern tributary valley during the Middle Ages and transferred the city name to this place in the form of Klenais.
In C. Bursian, Geographie von Griechenland, vol. II, p. 37, it says: "The site of the city on a hill on the west side of the valley is still recognizable by its ruins," and p. 38: "Even today, 1/4 hour southeast of its site, there is a khan (called the Khan of Kurtesa) and a barracks next to it to facilitate and secure traffic, while the valley itself has otherwise become deserted".]

In ancient times, there were two roads from Cleonae to Argos:
Pausan. II, 15, 1:
ἐκ Κλεωνῶν δέ εἴσιν ἐς Ἄργος ὁδοὶ δύο. ἡ μὲν ἀνδράσιν εὐζώνοις, καὶ ἐστὶν ἐπίτομος. ἡ δὲ ἐπὶ τοῦ καλουμένου Τρητοῦ στενὴ μὲν καὶ αὐτὴ περιεχόντων ὁρῶν, ὀχήμασι δέ ἐστιν ὅμως ἐπιτηδειοτέρα:
There are two roads from Cleonae to Argos. One is suitable for lightly-armed men and is a shortcut. The other passes through the so-called Tretus and is itself narrow since it is bounded by mountains, yet is somehow more suitable for vehicles.

However, it is not possible to determine with certainty which of these roads, or both, is the Kontoporia mentioned by Polybius XVI, 16 and Athenaeus as leading from Corinth to Mycenae. Ottfried Müller takes it to be the former (Dorier Th. I, S. 71; cf. G. 6. A. 1832, S. 130). On the other hand, Leake t. III, p. 328 finds it more likely that the shorter path over Aion Oros (ἅγιον ὄρος) is meant. One of the three reasons he gives for this is that the cold spring mentioned by Athenaeus, for which the Kontoporia is named, was located on a hilltop, which is difficult to understand from the former carriage road. [Bursian B. II, S. 38 remarks about the carriage road: "The carriage road ran from the valley out southwestwards to the western part of Tretus and crossed it, gradually ascending, in a narrow pass, in which one can still recognize in some places the ruts cut into the rock floor." The footpath mentioned by Pausanias leads him from the valley to the plain of Argos past the village of Hagios Basilios on the northern slope of Tretus. Neither Curtius a. a. O. S. 513 nor Bursian S. 9 identifies the Kontoporia with these roads, but both describe it as the shortest, straight line connection between Corinth and Argos. Cf. Ross Reisen und Reiserouten in Griechenland I, S. 25].

Von Kleonä führten im Alterthume zwei Wege nach Argos:
Pausan. II, 15, 1:
ἐκ Κλεωνῶν δέ εἴσιν ἐς Ἄργος ὁδοὶ δύο. ἡ μὲν ἀνδράσιν εὐζώνοις, καὶ ἐστὶν ἐπίτομος. ἡ δὲ ἐπὶ τοῦ καλουμένου Τρητοῦ στενὴ μὲν καὶ αὐτὴ περιεχόντων ὁρῶν, ὀχήμασι δέ ἐστιν ὅμως ἐπιτηδειοτέρα:
There are two roads from Cleonae to Argos. One is suitable for lightly-armed men and is a shortcut. The other passes through the so-called Tretus and is itself narrow since it is bounded by mountains, yet is somehow more suitable for vehicles.
ob aber einer von diesen und welcher die von Polybius XVI, 16 und Athenaeus erwähnte von Korinth
Athen. ΙΙ, 19
ἔγγιστα πρὸς δύσεις χειμερινάς
closest to the winter setting [of the sun]
nach Mykenä führende Κοντοπορία war, darüber sind die Meinungen getheilt. Ottfr. Müller nimmt sie für ersteren (Dorier Th. I, S. 71; vgl. G. 6. A. 1832, S. 130); dagegen findet es Leake t. III, p. 328 wahrscheinlicher, dass damit der heutige kürzere Weg über Aion Oros (ἅγιον ὄρος) gemeint sei; und von den drei Gründen, die er dafür anführt, ist allerdings der von Bedeutung, dass die kalte Quelle, um derenwillen Ath. l. c. der Κοντοπορία gedenkt, auf der Höhe (
κατὰ τὴν ἀκρώρειαν
on the hilltop ) lag, was sich von jenem Fahrwege kaum verstehen lässt. [Ueber den Fahrweg bemerkt Bursian B. II, S. 38: „Die Fahrstrasse zog sich vom Thale aus südwestwürts nach dem westlichen Theile des Tretos und durchschnitt denselben, allmälig aufsteigend, in einem Engpasse, in welchem man noch an einigen Stellen die in den Felsenboden eingeschnittenen Fahrgeleise erkennt.“ Den von Pausanius erwähnten Fusspfad lässt er am nördlichen Abhange des Tretos beim Dorfe Hagios Basilios vorüber vom Thale nach der Ebene von Argos führen. Die Kontoporia dagegen identificirt weder Curtius a. a. O. S. 513, noch Bursian S. 9 mit diesen Wegen, sondern beide bezeichnen sie als den kürzesten, geradlinigen Verbindungspfad zwischen Korinth und Argos. Vergl. Ross Reisen und Reiserouten in Griechenland I, S. 25].

Pausan. II, 15, 2:
ἐν τούτοις τοῖς ὄρεσι τὸ σπήλαιον ἔτι
δείκνυται τοῦ λέοντος.
In these mountains the cave of the lion is still pointed out.
Vergl. Dodwell p. 207, Leake p. 329, Unger Theb. Parad. p. 193.
Expédition de Morée tom. II, p. 147: distance totale: 2 heures, 5 minutes. Vgl. Curtius S. 414.
S. die Exc. über die Reise.

For comparison, let the description that Kybele gives of Theagenes be given here, from which the description of Charicles is almost literally taken.
Heliod. Aethiop. VII, 10:
εὑρύς τις ἦν τὰ στέρνα καὶ τοὺς ὥμους, καὶ τὸν αὐχένα ὄρϑιον καὶ ἐλεύϑερον ὑπὲρ τοὺς ἄλλους αἴρων, καὶ εἰς κορυφὴν τοὺς ἅπαντas ὑπερέχων, γλαυκιῶν τὸ βλέμμα καὶ ἑπέραστον ἅμα καὶ γοργὸν προσβλέπων, ἡ καταβόστρυχός που πάντως ἐκεῖνος, τὴν παρειὰν ἄρτι ξανϑῷ τῷ ἰούλῳ περιστέφων :
He was broad in the chest and shoulders, holding his neck upright and free above the others, and overtopping them all in height, blue-eyed and gazing with a look both loving and fiery, that one surely with clustering locks, just now winding his cheek with the blond down of youth.
cf.
Heliod. Aethiop. VII, 12:
βλέμμα γὰρ οὕτω λαμπρὸν καὶ εὐσχήμων ὄψις ἅμα καὶ ἐπέραστος εὐγενείας ἔμφασιν παρίστησιν.
For such a bright and well-ordered glance, loving yet noble, reveals high birth.

The shrubs and plants mentioned here are indeed the common ones in this area. Of the Tretos, see
Pouqueville p. 148:
the Tretos in which the river flows and the waters from the Rîto spring, amidst a thick thicket of myrtles, oleanders, and shrubs.
The holly, Ilex aquifolia L., Greek πρῖνος ἀγρία, Roman, aquifolium, is likewise frequent in this area:
Expéd. de Morée t. III, p. 35:
une campagne couverte de petits buissons et de houx,
a countryside covered with small bushes and holly
between Corinth and Nemea. The strawberry tree, Arbutus unedo, is native to all of Greece. The yellow sage, Salvia pomifera, Greek σφάκος, now ἀλφησικακία, grows plentifully in the area.
Dodwell p. 298:
this plant is common in the rocky places in Greece.
[Nevertheless, the oleander had to be removed from the text because, according to
V. Hehn Culturpflanzen und Hausthiere 2. Aufl. 1874, S. 358, it only migrated to Greece in the period between Theophrastus and the end of the Roman Republic.]

Die hier genannten Sträucher und Pflanzen sind in der That die in dieser Gegend gewöhnlichen. Vom Tretos sagt
Pouqueville p. 148:
le Trété, dans lequel coulent la rivière et les eaux de la source de Rîto au milieu d'un fourré épais de myrtes, de lauriers-roses et d'arbustes.
Die Stechpalme, Ilex aquifolia L., griech. πρῖνος ἀγρία, röm. aquifolium, ist ebenfalls in dieser Gegend häufig
Expéd. de Morée t. III, p. 35:
une campagne couverte de petits buissons et de houx,
zwischen Korinth und Nemea. Der Erdbeerbaum, Arbutus unedo, ist in ganz Griechenland heimisch. Der gelbe Salbey, Salvia pomifera, griech. σφάκος, jetzt ἀλησφακιά, wächst in der Umgegend in Menge.
Dodwell p. 298:
this plant is common in the rocky places in Greece.
[Dennoch musste im Texte der Oleander gestrichen werden, weil derselbe nach
V. Hehn Culturpflanzen und Hausthiere 2. Aufl. 1874, S. 358 erst in der Zeit zwischen Theophrast und dem Ende der römischen Republik in Griechenland eingewandert ist.]

The bushes and plants mentioned here are indeed the common ones in this area. Pouqueville says of Tretos:
Pouqueville p. 148:
le Trété, dans lequel coulent la rivière et les eaux de la source de Rîto au milieu d'un fourré épais de myrtes, de lauriers-roses et d'arbustes.
The holly, Ilex aquifolia L., Greek πρῖνος ἀγρία, Roman aquifolium, is also common in this area between Corinth and Nemea. The strawberry tree, Arbutus unedo, is native to all of Greece. The yellow sage, Salvia pomifera, Greek σφάκος, now ἀλησφακιά, grows in abundance in the vicinity. Dodwell says:
Dodwell p. 298:
this plant is common in the rocky places in Greece.
However, the oleander had to be deleted from the text because, according to V. Hehn, Culturpflanzen und Hausthiere 2. Aufl. 1874, S. 358, it only migrated to Greece between the time of Theophrastus and the end of the Roman Republic.
[At Becker's own request, K. F. Hermann changed it in place of "the fourth hour" in his edition of Charikles. For the matter, see the Exc. on Market and Trade.]

Dass die griechische Humanität den Reisenden gestattete, im Vorübergehen von den Früchten am Wege zu essen, daran darf man wohl nicht zweifeln. Vgl. das Epigramm der
Anthol. Pal. IX, 249:
εὐπέταλον γλαυκὰν ἀναδενδράδα τάνδε παρ᾽ ἄκραις
ἱδρυνϑεὶς λοφιαῖς Πὰν δ᾽ ἐπισκοπέω·
εἰ δέ σε πορφύροντος ἔχει πόϑος, ὦ παροδῖτα,
βότρυος, οὐ φϑονέω γαστρὶ χαριζομένῳ·
ἣν δὲ χερὶ ψαύσῃς κλοπίῃ μόνον, αὐτίκα δέξῃ
ὀζαλέην βάχτρου τήνδε καρηβαρίην.
Having established myself on this soft-leaved gray-green oak tree on the hilltop edges, I, Pan, keep watch. If you have a craving, traveler, for the dark cluster, I do not begrudge the belly its delight. But if you touch it with thieving hand only, at once you will receive a weighty blow of my staff on your head.
Plato, der die speciellsten Vorschriften giebt, in wie weit auch ein Einheimischer sich so etwas erlauben dürfe, sagt
Plat. Leg. VIII, p. 845:
ἐὰν δέ ξένος ἐπιδημήσας ὀπώρας ἐπιϑυμῇ φαγεῖν διαπορευόμενος τὰς ὁδούς, τῆς μὲν γενναίας (ὀπώρας, γενναίων σταφυλῶν ἣ σύκων) ἁπτέσϑω, ἐὰν βούληται, μεθ’ ἑνὸς ἀκολούϑου, χωρὶς τιμῆς, ξένια δεχόμενος· τῆς δὲ ἀγροίκου λεγομένης καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ὁ νόμος εἰργέτω μὴ κοινωνεῖν ἡμῖν τοὺς ξένους.
If a stranger visiting during the fruit season desires to eat some as he travels the roads, let him partake, if he wishes, of the choice fruits (of grapes or figs) without payment, accepting hospitality, together with one attendant. But the law should forbid strangers from sharing with us the common and such sorts of fruits.
Was er unter ὀπώρα γενναία und ὀπώρα ἀγροῖκος versteht, das lehren die folgenden Worte, wo er verordnet, wenn ein Fremder unwissentlich gegen dieses Gesetz gehandelt habe,
Plat. Leg. VIII, p. 845:
τὸν μὲν δοῦλον πληγαῖς κολάζειν, τὸν δὲ ἐλεύϑερον ἀποπέμπειν, νουϑετήσαντα καὶ διδάξαντα τῆς ἄλλης ὀπώρας ἅπτεσϑαι τῆς εἰς ἀπόϑεσιν ὀσταφίδος οἴνου τε καὶ ξηρῶν σύκων ἀνεπιτηδείου κεκτῆσϑαι.
The slave should be beaten as punishment, but the free man should be sent away after admonishing him and teaching that he should partake of the other harvest destined for drying into raisins and inferior figs.
Es werden also jedenfalls gewisse Sorten, z. B. Weintrauben, die nicht zum Moste benutzt werden, Tafeltrauben, gemeint, und darum heisst es vorher:

what is now called the noble grape or the figs named as noble.

Κίμων ὁ Ἀθηναῖος ἐν τοῖς ἀγροῖς καὶ τοῖς κήποις οὐδένα τοῦ καρποῦ καϑίστα φύλακα, ὅπως οἱ βουλόμενοι τῶν πολιτῶν εἰσιόντες ὁπωρίζωνται καὶ λαμβάνωσιν εἴ τινος δέοιντο τῶν ἐν τοῖς χωρίοις

There is no good reason to doubt that Greek humanity allowed travelers to eat the fruits by the wayside as they passed by. Cf. the epigram of th
Anthol. Pal. IX, 249:
εὐπέταλον γλαυκὰν ἀναδενδράδα τάνδε παρ᾽ ἄκραις
ἱδρυνϑεὶς λοφιαῖς Πὰν δ᾽ ἐπισκοπέω·
εἰ δέ σε πορφύροντος ἔχει πόϑος, ὦ παροδῖτα,
βότρυος, οὐ φϑονέω γαστρὶ χαριζομένῳ·
ἣν δὲ χερὶ ψαύσῃς κλοπίῃ μόνον, αὐτίκα δέξῃ
ὀζαλέην βάχτρου τήνδε καρηβαρίην.
Having established myself on this soft-leaved gray-green oak tree on the hilltop edges, I, Pan, keep watch. If you have a craving, traveler, for the dark cluster, I do not begrudge the belly its delight. But if you touch it with thieving hand only, at once you will receive a weighty blow of my staff on your head.
Plato, who provides the most specific regulations about to what extent even a local might allow themselves such a thing, says:
Plat. Leg. VIII, p. 845:
ἐὰν δέ ξένος ἐπιδημήσας ὀπώρας ἐπιϑυμῇ φαγεῖν διαπορευόμενος τὰς ὁδούς, τῆς μὲν γενναίας (ὀπώρας, γενναίων σταφυλῶν ἣ σύκων) ἁπτέσϑω, ἐὰν βούληται, μεθ’ ἑνὸς ἀκολούϑου, χωρὶς τιμῆς, ξένια δεχόμενος· τῆς δὲ ἀγροίκου λεγομένης καὶ τῶν τοιούτων ὁ νόμος εἰργέτω μὴ κοινωνεῖν ἡμῖν τοὺς ξένους.
If a stranger visiting during the fruit season desires to eat some as he travels the roads, let him partake, if he wishes, of the choice fruits (of grapes or figs) without payment, accepting hospitality, together with one attendant. But the law should forbid strangers from sharing with us the common and such sorts of fruits.
What he means by ὀπώρα γενναία choice fruit and ὀπώρα ἀγροῖκος common fruit, becomes clear from the following section, where he decrees that if a foreigner has unknowingly acted against this law,
Plat. Leg. VIII, p. 845:
τὸν μὲν δοῦλον πληγαῖς κολάζειν, τὸν δὲ ἐλεύϑερον ἀποπέμπειν, νουϑετήσαντα καὶ διδάξαντα τῆς ἄλλης ὀπώρας ἅπτεσϑαι τῆς εἰς ἀπόϑεσιν ὀσταφίδος οἴνου τε καὶ ξηρῶν σύκων ἀνεπιτηδείου κεκτῆσϑαι.
The slave should be beaten as punishment, but the free man should be sent away after admonishing him and teaching that he should partake of the other harvest destined for drying into raisins and inferior figs.
Therefore, in any case, certain types, e.g., wine grapes that are not used for must, table grapes, are meant, and that's why it is previously stated:

τὴν γενναίαν νῦν λεγομένην σταφυλὴν ἢ τὰ γενναῖα σῦκα ἐπονομαζόμενα.
what is now called the noble grape or the figs named as noble.

Die Sucht, einen langen Stammbaum berühmter Vorfahren aufzustellen und wo möglich die unmittelbare Abstammung seines Geschlechts von einem Gotte oder Heros nachweisen zu wollen, darf bei den Griechen nicht Wunder nehmen. Sie wird immer da am entschiedensten hervortreten, wo man sich dem auf die Gottheit zurückzuführenden Ursprunge des Menschengeschlechts am nächsten glaubt. Ueberdies gaben den späteren Geschlechtern die Genealogien berühmter Namen der frühesten Zeit ein treffliches Mittel in die Hände, bis auf den Urquell des Daseins zurückzugehen, und wo die Grenze zwischen Einheimischen und Fremden so scharf gezogen war, oder einzelne Geschlechter uralte Vorrechte genossen, da konnte Ahnenstolz keine auffallende Erscheinung sein, wenn er auch von dem Verständigen als thöricht bemitleidet und oft genug verspottet wurde. So z. B. The desire to establish a long family tree of famous ancestors and, if possible, to prove the direct descent of their family from a god or hero, should not surprise us in the Greeks. It will always appear most clearly where one believes that the origin of the human race, which can be traced back to the gods, is closest. Furthermore, the genealogies of famous names from the earliest times gave later generations a valuable means of going back to the source of existence, and where the boundary between natives and foreigners was so clearly drawn, or where individual families enjoyed ancient privileges, ancestral pride could not be a striking phenomenon, even if it was often pitied as foolish by the discerning and often enough mocked. For example,
Aristoph. Nub. 48:
ἔγημα Μεγακλέους τοῦ Μεγακλέους ἀδελφιδῆν,
I married the niece of Megacles the son of Megacles.
wo die Worte wohl eine Anspielung auf Alkibiades enthalten,
der sein Geschlecht von väterlicher Seite von Aias ableitete, dessen Mutter aber Deinomache, die Tochter des Megakles, zu den Alkmäoniden gehörte. Des Redners Andokides Stammbaum reichte nach Hellanikos bis zu Odysseus und demnach auch bis zu Hermes und Zeus, Plut. Alcib. 21. X Orat. p. 884 C, [der des Historikers Hekatäos nach Herod. II, 143 im sechzehnten Gliede ebenfalls bis zu einem Gott] hinauf. S. Wachsmuth B. I, S. 383. 555. Die belehrendste Stelle über die doppelte Ansicht von dem Werthe solches Erbadels findet sich bei Plato Theaetetus , dessen Urtheil um so grösseren Werth hat, als Plato selbst von väterlicher wie von mütterlicher Seite aus altem edlem Geschlechte abstammte : Here the words are probably an allusion to Alkibiades, who traced his lineage from his father's side to Aias, while his mother, Deinomache, the daughter of Megakles, belonged to the Alcmaeonids. The orator Andokides' family tree, according to Hellanicus, goes back to Odysseus and thus also to Hermes and Zeus, Plutarch, Alkibiades 21. X Orat. p. 884 C, [the family tree of the historian Hekataios, according to Herodotus II, 143, goes back to a god in the sixteenth generation] likewise. See Wachsmuth B. I, p. 383. 555.
Plato Theaet. p. 175:
τὰ δὲ δὴ γένη ὑμνούντων, ὡς γενναῖός τις ἑπτὰ πάππους πλουσίους ἔχων ἀποφῆναι, παντάπασιν ἀμβλὺ καὶ ἐπὶ σμικρὸν δρώντων ἡγεῖται (ὁ φιλόσοφος) τὸν ἔπαινον, ἀπὸ ἀπαιδευσίας οὐ δυναμένων εἰς τὸ πᾶν ἀεὶ βλέπειν οὐδὲ λογίζεσθαι, ὅτε πάππων καὶ προγόνων μυριάδες ἑκάστῳ γεγόνασιν ἀναρίϑμητοι, ἐν αἷς πλούσιοι καὶ πτωχοἰ, καὶ βασιλεῖς καὶ δοῦλοι, βάρβαροί τε καὶ Ἕλληνες πολλάκις μυρίοι γεγόνασιν ὁτῳοῦν· ἀλλ᾽ ἐπὶ πέντε καὶ εἴκοσι καταλόγῳ npoγόνων σεμνυνομένων καὶ ἀναφερόντων εἰς Ἠρακλέα τὸν Ἀμφιτρύωvos ἄτοπα αὐτῷ καταφαίνεται τῆς σμικρολογίας.
And when people extol lineages, as though one were proving himself noble by displaying seven wealthy ancestors, the philosopher regards their praise as utterly dull-witted and shortsighted, since out of lack of education they cannot look to the whole and recognize that each person has had myriads upon myriads of ancestors, among whom have been countless times ten thousand rich and poor, kings and slaves, barbarians and Greeks - anyone you please. But when people pride themselves on a pedigree of twenty-five ancestors and trace their lineage back to Heracles son of Amphitryon, their petty preciseness seems absurd to him.
[Vgl. Menander bei Stob. Serm. LXXXVII, 4, Lobeck Aglaoph. p. 764, K. Keil Zwei Inschr. aus Sparta und Gythion, 8.26. Böckh Corp. Inscr. I, 2, p. 421, n. 2568. Auch in der römischen Zeit blieb den Griechen diese Eitelkeit. Der berühmte Herodes Atticus leitete sein Geschlecht bis auf die Aeakiden zurück: Philostr. vitt. sophist. II. 1 und von dem prahlenden Eukleides sagt Martial Epigr. V, 35: longumque pulchra stemma repetit a Leda.]

longumque pulchra stemma repetit a Leda.
and traces a long and beautiful lineage from Leda.

Es geschah dies schon früher. So entschuldigt Helos seinen Vater bei
Antiph. de caede Herod. 78:
εἰ δ᾽ ἐν Αἴνῳ χωροφιλεῖ, τοῦτο οὐκ ἀποστερῶν γε τῶν εἰς τὴν πόλιν ἑαυτὸν οὐδενὸς οὐδ᾽ ἑτέρας πόλεως πολίτης γεγενημένος, ὥσπερ ἑτέρους ὁρῶ τοὺς μὲν εἰς τὴν ἤπειρον ἰόντας καὶ οἰκοῦντας ἐν τοῖς πολεμίοις τοῖς ὐμετέροις καὶ δίκας ἀπὸ ξυμβόλων ὁμῖν δικαζομένους.
But if he is fond of living in Aenos, in doing this he does not deprive himself of any service to the state, nor has he become a citizen of any other state, as I see some men do - some going to live on the continent and dwelling among your enemies and prosecuting legal disputes with you arising from commercial agreements.
Vgl. Lys.in Philon. 8. 9. Es wurde dies zwar Niemandem verwehrt, wie Plato. im Crito p.51 ausdrücklich sagt; allein gern konnte der Staat es natürlich nicht sehen, und insofern mochte es immer einen Vorwurf begründen. In Sparta stand Todesstrafe auf dem μετοικισμός: Plut. Agid. 11.

This happened before. Thus, Helos apologizes for his father at
Antiph. de caede Herod. 78:
εἰ δ᾽ ἐν Αἴνῳ χωροφιλεῖ, τοῦτο οὐκ ἀποστερῶν γε τῶν εἰς τὴν πόλιν ἑαυτὸν οὐδενὸς οὐδ᾽ ἑτέρας πόλεως πολίτης γεγενημένος, ὥσπερ ἑτέρους ὁρῶ τοὺς μὲν εἰς τὴν ἤπειρον ἰόντας καὶ οἰκοῦντας ἐν τοῖς πολεμίοις τοῖς ὐμετέροις καὶ δίκας ἀπὸ ξυμβόλων ὑμῖν δικαζομένους.
But if he is fond of living in Aenos, in doing this he does not deprive himself of any service to the state, nor has he become a citizen of any other state, as I see some men do - some going to live on the continent and dwelling among your enemies and prosecuting legal disputes with you arising from commercial agreements.
Cf. Lys.in Philon. 8. 9. This was not forbidden to anyone, as Plato explicitly states in Crito p.51. However, the state naturally did not like it, and in this sense, it could always be a cause for reproach. In Sparta, there was a death penalty for μετοικισμός: Plut. Agid. 11.

Der Grundsatz: ubi bene, ibi patria, ist nicht neu. Wie er das Motiv zu den Vögeln des Aristophanes ist, so lässt derselbe Dichter Plut. 1151 ihn unumwunden durch Hermes aussprechen:
Aristoph. Plut. 1151
πατρὶς γάρ ἐστι πᾶσ᾽, ἵν᾽ ἂν πράττῃ τις εὖ.
For everything is a fatherland wherever one can live well.
[Der römische Dichter Pacuvius gab diesen Satz in seinem Teucer so wieder:
Pacuvius, Teucer
patria est, ubicunque est bene
One's homeland is wherever one is well
, vgl. Cic. Tusc. V, 37 mit der Anm. von Davis. Dass die kosmopolitisch gesinnten Sophisten demselben Grundsatze huldigten [Plat. Tim. p. kann nicht befremden.]

The principle: ubi bene, ibi patria where it is well, there is my fatherland. is not new. Just as it is the motif for Aristophanes' 'The Birds', the same poet unreservedly has Hermes express it in:
Aristoph. Plut. 1151
πατρὶς γάρ ἐστι πᾶσ᾽, ἵν᾽ ἂν πράττῃ τις εὖ.
For everything is a homeland wherever one can live well.
[The Roman poet Pacuvius repeated this sentence in his Teucer in this way:
Pacuvius, Teucer
patria est, ubicunque est bene
One's homeland is wherever one is well
. Compare Cicero, Tusculan Disputations, V, 37 with the note of Davis. It is not surprising that the cosmopolitan-minded Sophists adhered to the same principle (Plato, Timaeus, p. 19).]

The Greek, it seems, looked forward to the first appearance of birds, whose return heralds the spring, even more eagerly than we do. Hence the proverbial cry of joy ὥρα νέα, χελιδών .
Aristoph. Equit. 419:
Σκέφψασϑε, παῖδες, οὐχ ὁρᾶϑ'; ὥρα νέα, χελιδών.
look, children, don't you see? A new season -- the swallow.
and the comic lament of Mnesilochos
Thesmoph. 1:
ὦ Ζεῦ, χελιδὼν ἆρα πότε φανήσεται;
O Zeus, when will the swallow appear?
[Especially relevant here is the Rhodian lullaby
Athen. VII, 60 p. 360:
ἦλθ᾽, ἦλϑε χελιδών,
καλὰς ὥρας ἄγουσα,
καλοὺς ἐνιαυτούς,
ἐπὶ γαστέρα λευκά,
ἐπὶ νῶτα μέλαινα. κ. τ. λ.
The swallow has come, the swallow has come,
bringing the fair seasons,
bringing the good years,
upon her white belly,
upon her black back, etc.
Even today, children in Greece sing a similar song on March 1st, by turning a wooden swallow on a cylinder: G. Wolff im Philol. Anz. 1872, IV, 8. 144. Vase paintings: Monum. ined. dell’ Instit. arch. II, 24 mit Panofka in den Annali 1835, t. VII, p. 233-242.] — Even the proverb "One swallow does not make a summer" is literally the same in Greek.
Aristot. Ethic. Nicom. I, 6, p. 1098:
μία γὰρ χελιδὼν ἔαρ οὐ ποιεῖ.
A single swallow does not make it spring.
The kite, ἴκτινος, which appears even earlier, was greeted with joy in the same way..
Aristoph. Av. 712:
ἴκτινος δ᾽ αὖ μετὰ ταῦτα φανεὶς ἑτέραν ὥραν ἀποφαίνει,
ἡνίκα πεκτεῖν ὥρα προβάτων πόκον ἠρινόν· εἶτα χελιδών,
ὅτε χρὴ χλαῖναν πωλεῖν ἤδη καὶ ληδάριόν τι πρίασϑαι.
And then the kite appears, announcing another season,
when it is time to pluck the spring fleece of the sheep; then the swallow,
when one must now sell one's cloak and buy a light coat.
The exuberant joy over their arrival is expressed by the idiom
v. 500
προκυλίνδεσθαι τοῖς ἰκτίνοις
to tumble forward at the hoopoes
, on which the Scholiast remarks:
Scholiast
ἔαρος ἀρχομένου ἴκτινος φαίνεται εἰς τὴν Ἑλλάδα, ἐφ᾽ ᾧ ἡδόμενοι κυλίνδονται.
At the beginning of spring the hoopoe appears in Greece, at which they [?] roll about in delight.
Die von Demosth. de cor. 129 u. 258 erwähnte Schule, wo Aeschines und sein Vater niedere Dienste verrichteten.
The school mentioned by Demosthenes in de cor. 129 and 258, where Aeschines and his father did menial work.

cit.quote: ὁρᾶν δ᾽ ἦν ἐπὶ μὲν τῶν ϑυρῶν γυναῖκας ἐλευϑέρας, περιφόβους, κατεπτηκυίας καὶ πυνϑανομένας, εἰ ζῶσι, τὰς μὲν ὑπὲρ ἀνδρός, τὰς δ' ὑπὲρ πατρός, τὰς δ᾽ ὑπὲρ ἀδελφῶν, ἀναξίως αὑτῶν καὶ τῆς πόλεως ὁρωμένας. τῶν δὲ ἀνδρῶν τοὺς τοῖς σώμασιν ἀπειρηκότας καὶ τὰς ἡλικίας πρεσβυτέρους καὶ ὑπὸ τῶν νόμων τοῦ στρατεύεσθαι ἀφειμένους ἰδεῖν ἦν καθ᾽ ὅλην τὴν πόλιν ἐπὶ γήρως ὁδῷ περιφϑειρομένους, διπλᾶ τὰ ἱμάτια ἐμπεπορπημένους. πολλῶν δὲ καὶ δεινῶν κατὰ τήν πόλιν γιγνομένων καὶ πάντων τῶν πολιτῶν τὰ μέγιστα ἠτυκηκότων, μάλιστ᾽ ἄν τις ἤλγησε καὶ ἐδάκρυεν ἐπὶ ταῖς τῆς πόλεως συμφοραῖς, ἡνίχ᾽ ὁρᾶν ἦν τὸν δῆμον φηφισάμενον τοὺς μὲν δούλους ἐλευϑέρους, τοὺς δὲ ξένους Ἀθηναίους, τοὺς δ᾽ ἀτίμους ἐπιτίμους.

One could see at the doors freeborn women, frightened and crouching, asking if their loved ones were alive - some for a husband, some for a father, some for brothers - a sight unworthy of them and of the city. Of the men, one could see those exhausted in body and advanced in years, exempt by law from military service, making their way with staffs throughout the whole city, wrapped in double cloaks. And though many terrible things were happening in the city and all the citizens had suffered greatly, one would have felt the most pain and wept for the misfortunes of the city, when one saw the people voting to free the slaves, make foreigners citizens, and restore civil rights to the disenfranchised.
